articles.headline: A Disappearing Spy, and a Scandal at the C.I.A.
articles.snippet: When Robert A. Levinson disappeared in Iran in 2007, U.S. officials insisted he was a private investigator. In fact, he was a C.I.A. contractor.
articles.abstract: When Robert A. Levinson disappeared in Iran in 2007, U.S. officials insisted he was a private investigator. In fact, he was a C.I.A. contractor.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert A. Levinson was an overweight bear of a man who once worked as an F.B.I. agent and desperately wanted to recapture the life of international intrigue he relished as an expert on Russian organized crime. But as he sat in a hotel room in Geneva in early 2007, he was anxious about a secret mission he had planned to Iran.

articles.headline: Underdog Against Amazon, Best Buy Charges Ahead
articles.snippet: Best Buy stock is one of the best-performing stocks in the Standard & Poor’s 500, leading rival retailers to wonder how the company did it.
articles.abstract: Best Buy stock is one of the best-performing stocks in the Standard & Poor’s 500, leading rival retailers to wonder how the company did it.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was a lonely holiday season last year for David Strasser, an analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott. Of the 25 analysts covering the electronics retailer Best Buy, he was the only one to make a buy recommendation. And the stock kept going down.

articles.headline: Billionaire Drops Plan for Casino in Spain
articles.snippet: Some civic and religious groups in Spain sought to block the EuroVegas project, but advocates saw it as a potential stimulus to the weak economy.
articles.abstract: Some civic and religious groups in Spain sought to block the EuroVegas project, but advocates saw it as a potential stimulus to the weak economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID — Sheldon G. Adelson, the billionaire casino magnate, on Friday abandoned his plans to build a $30 billion gambling and leisure resort on the outskirts of Madrid after failing to win financial concessions and other favors from the Spanish government.
articles.byline: By Raphael Minder and Landon Thomas Jr

articles.headline: An Alternative to Giving Up the Car Keys
articles.snippet: The number of older drivers on the road is growing, but technology and training could keep them behind the wheel safely for longer.
articles.abstract: The number of older drivers on the road is growing, but technology and training could keep them behind the wheel safely for longer.
articles.lead_paragraph: Robert Cullon, 80, has a neurological condition that makes his feet numb and forces him to rely on a walker. He thought he was driving just fine, but his six children were worried.

articles.headline: The Most-Wanted Stocking Stuffer: Cash
articles.snippet: Money might seem an impersonal gift, but it is usually welcome from anyone trying to pay tuition or student loans, and there are imaginative ways to give it.
articles.abstract: Money might seem an impersonal gift, but it is usually welcome from anyone trying to pay tuition or student loans, and there are imaginative ways to give it.
articles.lead_paragraph: All Elizabeth Starkey wants for Christmas is a little help paying her student loans.

articles.headline: British Wine Benefits as the Climate Changes
articles.snippet: By midcentury, Britain could become one of the world’s big wine producers, as warmer weather moves the limits of viticulture ever farther north.
articles.abstract: By midcentury, Britain could become one of the world’s big wine producers, as warmer weather moves the limits of viticulture ever farther north.
articles.lead_paragraph: DORKING, England — For more than a decade, Matthieu Elzinga ran his own vineyard in the western Loire Valley of France. But this year, just as he was gaining an international reputation for his dry and crisp Muscadets, Mr. Elzinga sold the vineyard and moved to an emerging wine region: the south of England.

articles.headline: To Lower Tariffs, Vietnam Pushes for Easing Trade Rules
articles.snippet: Vietnam helps supply much of the apparel worn in the Western world, and negotiations with Europe are being watched with especially close care.
articles.abstract: Vietnam helps supply much of the apparel worn in the Western world, and negotiations with Europe are being watched with especially close care.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — The executives came from companies that own brands like Nike, Levi’s and Zara.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim and Tuan Nguyen

articles.headline: Land Disputes Slow Recovery in Philippines
articles.snippet: Squatters have long been able to settle on others’ land, but after Typhoon Haiyan some landowners have thwarted rebuilding efforts.
articles.abstract: Squatters have long been able to settle on others’ land, but after Typhoon Haiyan some landowners have thwarted rebuilding efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: TACLOBAN, the Philippines — A mile offshore from this typhoon-wrecked city lies a postcard-perfect tropical islet fringed with golden sand beaches and topped with a mansion and swimming pool: the private island of one of this country’s most powerful families, the Romualdez clan of the former first lady, Imelda Marcos.

articles.headline: Boehner’s Jabs at Activist Right Show G.O.P. Shift
articles.snippet: Speaker John A. Boehner seethed and questioned the motives of conservative advocacy groups after they piled on against a new bipartisan budget deal.
articles.abstract: Speaker John A. Boehner seethed and questioned the motives of conservative advocacy groups after they piled on against a new bipartisan budget deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — While Speaker John A. Boehner was harsh in his public criticism of conservative advocacy groups opposed to a new bipartisan budget deal, his attack on the organizations was even more pointed when he was behind closed doors.

articles.headline: In 2 States, Corner Cannabis Store Nears Reality
articles.snippet: The sale of the drug will be legal in Colorado and Washington next month, and some observers predict other states will soon follow suit.
articles.abstract: The sale of the drug will be legal in Colorado and Washington next month, and some observers predict other states will soon follow suit.
articles.lead_paragraph: DENVER — Starting early next year, any adult with a craving or curiosity will be able to stroll into a strip mall or downtown shop in Colorado or Washington State and do what has long been forbidden: buy a zip-lock bag of legal marijuana.
articles.byline: By Jack Healy and Kirk Johnson

articles.headline: Google Adds to Its Menagerie of Robots
articles.snippet: Boston Dynamics and its animal kingdom-themed machines bring significant cachet to Google’s robotic efforts.
articles.abstract: Boston Dynamics and its animal kingdom-themed machines bring significant cachet to Google’s robotic efforts.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — BigDog, Cheetah, WildCat and Atlas have joined Google’s growing robot menagerie.

articles.headline: Officials Say U.S. May Never Know Extent of Snowden’s Leaks
articles.snippet: Investigators remain in the dark partly because the facility where the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden worked was not equipped with software to monitor employees.
articles.abstract: Investigators remain in the dark partly because the facility where the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden worked was not equipped with software to monitor employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American intelligence and law enforcement investigators have concluded that they may never know the entirety of what the former National Security Agency contractor Edward J. Snowden extracted from classified government computers before leaving the United States, according to senior government officials.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: Wake Up the Banking Police
articles.snippet: The Volcker Rule approved by regulators will prove to be of little value if banking regulators fail to enforce its provisions.
articles.abstract: The Volcker Rule approved by regulators will prove to be of little value if banking regulators fail to enforce its provisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Volcker Rule has landed. Will the United States financial system be safer and sounder as a result?

articles.headline: Samsung: Uneasy in the Lead
articles.snippet: While the Korean industrial group dominates some electronics categories, its chairman, Lee Kun-hee, warns employees against complacency.
articles.abstract: While the Korean industrial group dominates some electronics categories, its chairman, Lee Kun-hee, warns employees against complacency.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lee Kun-hee, the man who built the most successful, most admired and most feared business in Asia — a $288 billion behemoth that is among the most profitable in the world — had a message for his employees this year: You must do better.
articles.byline: By Eric Pfanner and Brian X. Chen

articles.headline: Cook Islands, a Paradise of Untouchable Assets
articles.snippet: These flyspeck islands in the Pacific have the reputation of being a place where assets can be hidden from business partners, litigants or former spouses.
articles.abstract: These flyspeck islands in the Pacific have the reputation of being a place where assets can be hidden from business partners, litigants or former spouses.
articles.lead_paragraph: Picture a paradise where you can be lawsuit-proof. A place to hide your hard-earned assets far from the grasp of former or soon-to-be-former spouses, angry business partners or, if you happen to be a doctor, patients who might sue you.

articles.headline: Japan’s Top Voice: High, Polite and on the Phone
articles.snippet: The annual All-Japan Phone-Answering Competition for office workers is a closely watched contest that some say reiterates the stereotype of women in clerical positions.
articles.abstract: The annual All-Japan Phone-Answering Competition for office workers is a closely watched contest that some say reiterates the stereotype of women in clerical positions.
articles.lead_paragraph: SENDAI, Japan — The contestants roll their shoulders and lick their lips. The audience holds its breath. At the center of attention on stage at an expansive convention hall: a single telephone.

articles.headline: Far Right in Eastern Europe Makes Gains as Syrians Arrive
articles.snippet: A party known as Ataka, which means attack, champions “Bulgaria for Bulgarians” and has denounced Syrian refugees as terrorists whom Bulgaria, the European Union’s poorest nation, must expel.
articles.abstract: A party known as Ataka, which means attack, champions “Bulgaria for Bulgarians” and has denounced Syrian refugees as terrorists whom Bulgaria, the European Union’s poorest nation, must expel.
articles.lead_paragraph: SVILENGRAD, Bulgaria — After spreading turmoil and desperate refugees across the Middle East, Syria’s brutal civil war has now leaked misery into Europe’s eastern fringe — and put a spring in the step of Angel Bozhinov, a nationalist activist in this Bulgarian border town next to Turkey.

articles.headline: China Focusing Graft Inquiry on Ex-Official
articles.snippet: The decision by President Xi Jinping to investigate the former head of the domestic security apparatus is the first time that such a high-level official has been the focus of a formal corruption inquiry.
articles.abstract: The decision by President Xi Jinping to investigate the former head of the domestic security apparatus is the first time that such a high-level official has been the focus of a formal corruption inquiry.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Sending tremors across China’s political landscape, President Xi Jinping and other party leaders have authorized a corruption inquiry against the powerful former head of the domestic security apparatus, Zhou Yongkang, according to sources with elite political ties.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Ansfield and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: Beyoncé Rejects Tradition for Social Media’s Power
articles.snippet: The pop star bypassed the standard practice of relentless promotion when she released her album last week, and the impressive response may have blazed a new trail for the music industry.
articles.abstract: The pop star bypassed the standard practice of relentless promotion when she released her album last week, and the impressive response may have blazed a new trail for the music industry.
articles.lead_paragraph: The release of a blockbuster album has historically come with a few standard marketing moves. Flood the radio with an early single. Book as many TV appearances as possible. Line up partnerships with big retailers and consumer brands.

articles.headline: Sheriffs Refuse to Enforce Laws on Gun Control
articles.snippet: The resistance of sheriffs in Colorado to enforcing certain gun laws is raising questions about whether tougher rules passed since Newtown have a muted effect in parts of the nation where gun ownership is common.
articles.abstract: The resistance of sheriffs in Colorado to enforcing certain gun laws is raising questions about whether tougher rules passed since Newtown have a muted effect in parts of the nation where gun ownership is common.
articles.lead_paragraph: GREELEY, Colo. — When Sheriff John Cooke of Weld County explains in speeches why he is not enforcing the state’s new gun laws, he holds up two 30-round magazines. One, he says, he had before July 1, when the law banning the possession, sale or transfer of the large-capacity magazines went into effect. The other, he “maybe” obtained afterward.

articles.headline: G.O.P. Firebrands Tone Down Their Message and Run Again
articles.snippet: Republican candidates who benefited from the Tea Party in 2010, but lost two years later, hope to rebound next year by focusing on the health care law.
articles.abstract: Republican candidates who benefited from the Tea Party in 2010, but lost two years later, hope to rebound next year by focusing on the health care law.
articles.lead_paragraph: LIBERTYVILLE, Ill. — “My name is Congressman Bob Dold!” said the fleece-clad man making his way through a popular restaurant here.

articles.headline: AOL Chief’s White Whale Finally Slips His Grasp
articles.snippet: Tim Armstrong, the chief executive of AOL, had a sentimental, and some would say debilitating, attachment to Patch, a network of local news sites that he is finally winding down.
articles.abstract: Tim Armstrong, the chief executive of AOL, had a sentimental, and some would say debilitating, attachment to Patch, a network of local news sites that he is finally winding down.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tim Armstrong, the chief executive of AOL, is finally winding down Patch, a network of local news sites that he helped invent and that AOL bought after he took over.

articles.headline: Booksellers Wary About Holiday Sales
articles.snippet: Competition from e-books has eased, but merchants face other obstacles during their most crucial sales period.
articles.abstract: Competition from e-books has eased, but merchants face other obstacles during their most crucial sales period.
articles.lead_paragraph: All across the country, booksellers have a Christmas wish: that the e-book thrill is gone.

articles.headline: Tech Companies Press for a Better Retail Experience
articles.snippet: The investments in electronics retailing reflect a belief that companies should obsess over the environment in which products are presented to the public.
articles.abstract: The investments in electronics retailing reflect a belief that companies should obsess over the environment in which products are presented to the public.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Looking for a holiday gift? Come on in. Relax. Take a seat in the leather chair.

articles.headline: More Retailers See Haggling as a Price of Doing Business
articles.snippet: Consumers have become bolder, and they know that they often have the upper hand during a tough season for retailers, who must compete with steep online discounts.
articles.abstract: Consumers have become bolder, and they know that they often have the upper hand during a tough season for retailers, who must compete with steep online discounts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pay no attention to the price on that tag.

articles.headline: Surge Seen in U.S. Oil Output, Lowering Gasoline Prices
articles.snippet: A report predicted that the world oil benchmark price over the next few years would slip from a 2012 average of $112 a barrel to $92 a barrel in 2017.
articles.abstract: A report predicted that the world oil benchmark price over the next few years would slip from a 2012 average of $112 a barrel to $92 a barrel in 2017.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — Domestic oil production will continue to soar for years to come, the Energy Department predicted on Monday, scaling to levels not seen in nearly half a century by 2016.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Stanley Reed
